title: AWS S3 Bucket Policy Bypass via Confused Deputy Attack

timeline.event: Security researchers discover confused deputy vulnerability in S3 bucket policies
AWS releases security bulletin and mitigation guidance

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical vulnerability was discovered in how AWS S3 bucket policies handle cross-account access. Attackers can exploit the 'confused deputy' problem to access S3 buckets they shouldn't have access to. This happens when bucket policies don't properly validate the source of requests.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any AWS customer using S3 bucket policies with cross-account access, especially those using third-party services that access their S3 buckets. Organizations with broadly permissive bucket policies are most at risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker identifies S3 buckets with permissive cross-account policies. Step 2: They use a compromised or malicious AWS account to assume a trusted role. Step 3: The attacker's requests appear to come from a trusted source. Step 4: They gain unauthorized read/write access to sensitive data. Step 5: Data exfiltration or manipulation occurs undetected.
what_you_should_do: Review all S3 bucket policies for overly permissive cross-account access
Add aws:SourceAccount and aws:SourceArn conditions to all bucket policies
Enable S3 Access Logging and CloudTrail data events
Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer to identify public or cross-account access
Implement SCPs to restrict S3 access patterns organization-wide
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: S3 buckets often contain the most sensitive data in an organization - customer data, backups, application secrets, and intellectual property. A confused deputy attack bypasses normal authentication, making it nearly invisible to detection. Your data could be stolen without any alerts firing.

tactics.description: Attackers leverage compromised or malicious cloud accounts to initiate the attack
Attackers access and collect data stored in S3 buckets
Data is exfiltrated through legitimate AWS API calls

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor CloudTrail logs for unusual S3 access patterns, especially from unfamiliar AWS accounts or roles. Pay attention to cross-account access requests.

log_sources.description: Enable data events for S3 to capture object-level API activity
Detailed logs of all requests made to S3 buckets
Threat detection for unusual S3 access patterns

what_to_look_for.description: S3 API calls from AWS accounts not in your organization
Large number of GetObject calls in short time periods
S3 access from AWS regions you don't operate in

immediate_actions.description: Review all bucket policies for overly permissive Principal statements
Update bucket policies to include aws:SourceAccount conditions
Use Access Analyzer to find publicly accessible or cross-account resources
Ensure S3 data events are being logged for forensic analysis
